text:
- Hi, I'm Soumya Banerjee,
associate partner at McKinsey,
focused on cybersecurity and risk.
When it comes to generative AI,

so many organizations are
doing proof of concepts

and trying to get
something into the market
pretty quick and fast.
The challenge with that is,

are we considering the
right security implications?
Because if we don't get them right,

there are a lot of
situations that can happen.

It's like, you know, someone
on the prompt looking for,

you know, salaries of
other employees or biases,

or you're just exposing your
company to a lot of litigations
or privacy breach issues.

So I think it's important
to think about security
as built in versus bolted on

when it comes to generative
AI projects or solutions
that you are thinking of.
A few things to consider:

there is also the context
of your organization
and your controls and capability.

For example, is your
cybersecurity controls, you know,

capable enough to manage the
alerts that would come out
in case there's a security alert
coming out of the generative AI solution?

What is the data
classification, data governance,
and how you're training your models
in the context of your organization?

And then finally, it's about
resilience and response.

Meaning, if there are some
issues in terms of generative AI
that has a security issue,

how prepared are your
capabilities and controls
to respond to that issue
in a timely and in appropriate manner?

And then how are you
going to continue business
and you know, have resilience around it
in case something does not work

or if there are some
compromises that are happening?
(bright music)
